div.span: kathryn: ok, so i don't know what the problem is, but I think the solution is to have it be its own state and template, separate from stacks_list
I think that the problem is that you were trying to have all this stuff going on inside a ui-view, which is replaced by angular-ui when switching states
so maybe when it got swapped back to the default content, it added stuff to the scope? i couldn't see that happening but that's my guess. I think it's bad form to have stuff inside a ui-view.
does that make sense? ui-view is primarily just a placeholder for nested views, and i'm not sure what's going on behind the scenes when there's default content there

message.div: can you send me the code again?

div.span: i have a ui-view and i need to show that subview
can you not do that? have a <ui-view> surround sref?
i need to embed it inside
that's what it is right now, but instead it needs to show in the template
stacks.admin needs to show inside of the /stacks route if admin==true

message.div: because otherwise it will still exist in the DOM for non-admin users
but you can't use ng-switch inside of an ng-repeat

div.span: that wouldn't render in the dom right?

message.div: it just adds display:none to the style

div.span: weirdly ng-if complains "Cannot read property 'name' of null where ng-show works

message.div: what is null supposed to be?

div.span: there is no property 'name' to begin with
sorry, that's devoid of any context, ignore this

message.div: you have to put them in a 'views' property
.state 'stacks.admin', views: '@stacks.admin': templateUrl: "app/stacks/admin_publishing.main.html" 'adminPublisher@stacks.admin': templateUrl: "app/stacks/admin_publishing.tpl.html"

div.span: and here's a directive i'm trying to write
the thing i'm trying to accomplish is to have a watcher on each stack that watches for a change in date
and updates the date without having to refresh the page
the way to do that, if i've understood correctly, is to have a directive with scope of stack
but if i put the entire template there, it divorces things like the checkboxes from their watched scope
and i don't understand how to put the ng-model stackPublishedDate inside the same scope

message.div: i can't see the code cause it's all pink!

div.span: now you highlighted the whole thing blue and i can't see anything!
it's a property that will always stay constant on the stack

message.div: i thought it goes before the pipe

div.span: <li ng-repeat="person in attendees | filter: {arrived: false } track by person.id">
item in items | orderBy:'toString()' track by $index
i'm passing in the scope stack
in order to track each stack
and to know when the property published_at has been changed
but that's what's failing right now

message.div: can you not name them the same? it gets confusing to read which directives you've made and which are defaulted by angular
so make it nb-stack directive with a stack model
no you'd have to do this
now there are competing directives (made-up term)
it's weird to have ng-repeat on a directive
so I feel like it's better to put the repeat on the tr and the nb-stack inside

div.span: but do you see that then there's a problem of things like the checkboxes being out of scope?
they need to be able to communicate with the main controller on the app
they need to know their index number

message.div: which is that you want to be transcluding nbstack
but you don't have that set up
nb stack actually doesn't have a template
so no markup is being made (i don't think)
